bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 16, 1941

div1.p: Hench explains the Kissinger's situation and wants Kean to write them a note suggesting a veterans' hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 16, 1941
div1.opener:
July 16/41
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
DR. PHILIP S. HENCH
DR. CHARLES H. SLOCUMB
July 16, 1941
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
As I wrote you, I have had several rather plaintive
letters from Mrs. Kissinger, telling about the difficulties she is
having in taking care of Mr. Kissinger adequately. She almost complains
more about her ailments than his, and says that they have not enough
money to get any nursing help. Her rather severe backache interferes
greatly with her clothing him and taking care of him. I believe he
is now able to sit up some but speaks with considerable difficulty
and “will not let her out of his sight.” Hoping to lighten their
burden I got the name of his physician from Mrs. Kissinger and wrote
him the enclosed letter. So far I have had no reply. Maybe my intrusion
annoyed the physician although I thought I was diplomatic in my language.
Obviously, I cannot do anything more directly at the moment. I cannot
write to Mrs. Kissinger and suggest that he be transferred to a veterans'
hospital or the family physician will think I am taking the case away.

If you think, from what I have told you, that it would
help for us to have him in a veterans' hospital you might care to write
a brief note to her expressing your sympathy and just casually mention
the possibility that he might be cared for in a veterans' hospital.
If, however, you feel that you should keep out of it, I will understand
entirely.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, Philip S Hench P. S. Hench, M. D.
I have another letter to you
in progress. Will send it
shortly. It is about my
YF researches etc; what
I found in Washington etc
